text: Historian Eric Hobsbawm argued that the Industrial Revolution brought about sweeping social and economic changes that benefited some but left the working class in poor conditions. He suggested that industrialization widened the gap between the wealthy and the poor, creating new forms of exploitation and challenging traditional social structures.
text2: Economist Deirdre McCloskey countered that the Industrial Revolution ultimately led to higher living standards across all classes. McCloskey argued that industrialization sparked innovation, which created jobs, improved productivity, and eventually raised wages and living conditions, suggesting that the benefits extended even to the working class over time.
question: Based on the texts, how would McCloskey (Text 2) likely respond to Hobsbawm’s (Text 1) view of the Industrial Revolution as primarily exploitative for the working class? Use specific reasoning to support your answer.
A: By suggesting that, while initial hardships occurred, industrialization ultimately improved conditions for all classes, including the working class.
B: By arguing that the Industrial Revolution did not create any new jobs or innovation.
C: By agreeing that the Industrial Revolution only benefited the wealthy while harming the working class.
D: By asserting that the Industrial Revolution had no impact on social or economic structures.
explanation: B is the best answer. McCloskey believes that while industrialization may have had initial hardships, it ultimately led to economic growth that improved living conditions across classes, countering Hobsbawm’s focus on exploitation.Choice A is incorrect; McCloskey views the benefits as extending to all classes over time.Choice C is incorrect; McCloskey acknowledges significant social and economic impacts.Choice D is incorrect; McCloskey argues that the Industrial Revolution brought innovation and job creation.
